Answer: Yes there isWhen I worked at Intel and the company was growing very rapidly, Gordon Moore one calculated and shared that if Intel kept growing at its recent CAGR for enough years, it would ultimately have Revenues larger than Global GDP, clearly a logical impossibility. Answer: Theoretically, no, but there is a catch. Throughout the history, there has been only handful of companies able to reach the market cap of 1 trillion dollars USD, and no company ever maintained that 1 trillion dollar market cap.Among US companies, Apple briefly reached 1 trillion market cap twice but got back down. Microsoft also recently reached 1 trillion market cap but went back down as well. If you look at Amazon, Microsoft, Apple, and Google, these companies all have the potential to surpass the 1 trillion dollar market cap but no company ever did. Why?1 trillion dollar is a very huge valuTheoretically, no, but there is a catch. Throughout the history, there has been only handful of companies able to reach the market cap of 1 trillion dollars USD, and no company ever maintained that 1 trillion dollar market cap.Among US companies, Apple briefly reached 1 trillion market cap twice but got back down. Microsoft also recently reached 1 trillion market cap but went back down as well. If you look at Amazon, Microsoft, Apple, and Google, these companies all have the potential to surpass the 1 trillion dollar market cap but no company ever did. Why?1 trillion dollar is a very huge value even for a company like the size of these Amazon, Microsoft, Apple, and Google. To grow and to maintain such a ultra mega-cap sized company, the company has to be some kind of conglomerates that need to reach the variety of industries and become all successful at these fields. This is exactly why Google is trying to capture the hardware markets with Google Pixel and Google Nest while looking for other moon-shots like Waymo or other Google Cloud leveraged ventures like Google Stadia. This is exactly why Amazon bought Wholefoods, try something off-line concept using Amazon Go, and pursue the venture in space industry. Microsoft wants to steal some market share from Amazon Web Service cloud and want to pursue Microsoft Hololense and other ventures. Apple now wants to become more than a hardware company by selling Apple Music.Will they be profitable and keep growing forever? Possibly, yes. Many of these companies and few not mentioned like Facebook all have a decent shot at breaking through 1 trillion dollars market cap and keep growing further. But, again, making an idea is just one thing, while executing it well and actually turning the idea into another billion dollar worth of revenue industry is even a bigger and challenging feat. We have to put our AR glasses and observe how everything unfolds.So, the short answer is: theoretically yes, but very challenging based on the historical data.

They attract huge swaths of top talent from all walks of life from elite tech schools and business schools to senior executives and distingPut it this way— it's theirs to lose.The big guys: Amazon, Facebook, Google, Apple… all of them are dominant at what they do. They have amassed huge economies of scale and infrastructure that serve as moats to keep smaller companies from effectively competing. They attract huge swaths of top talent from all walks of life from elite tech schools and business schools to senior executives and distinguished principal engineers from the other top companies out there. They can afford to pay the best and they know that A-players want to work with other A-players. These are the New York Yankees of tech. How can you beat that?Innovation. Sears used to be Amazon. You could buy freaking anything- clothes, tools, tractors, even houses off of the Sears catalog. Just wait 6–8 weeks for it to ship and it will come to your door, or you can come pick it up in your semi-retired conveniently located local store.K-Mart came in and ate a large slice of their pie by selling a smaller selection of fast moving goods at a discount (purchasing economy) and locating closer to customers.Then Wal-Mart came in with a superior supply chain strategy and was able to undercut k-Mart prices and offer more selection to boot.Then Amazon revolutionized the shopping world with free two day shipping and a selection of just about everything in the world.So what's next in retail? If Amazon keeps its eyes open, they have the talent and horsepower to stay King of the Hill. But if they get complacent, some other company will change the rules right out from under them and win the advantage. This has some good parts and bad parts about it. Huge companies with such a control over the populous create such a monopoly that it is very hard if not impossible for a new company to start or compete. They will also control the market. Answer: This is an interesting delima that stops countless entrepreneurs. So let me tell you how I overcame this obstacle.First, let me paint the picture. I was a new single father of 4 young children. (Full custody) And after a year of commuting from PA to my job in DC, I just couldn't do it anymore and I lost my job.So I decided to start my own business. I borrowed from family and I dipped into the modest savings I had. This first business had a nice run (24 months), but after signing a bad deal with a national distributor, the business failed. I was broke and already $100's of thousands in debt toThis is an interesting delima that stops countless entrepreneurs. So let me tell you how I overcame this obstacle.First, let me paint the picture. I was a new single father of 4 young children. (Full custody) And after a year of commuting from PA to my job in DC, I just couldn't do it anymore and I lost my job.So I decided to start my own business. I borrowed from family and I dipped into the modest savings I had. This first business had a nice run (24 months), but after signing a bad deal with a national distributor, the business failed. I was broke and already $100's of thousands in debt to friends, family and vendors.However, I didn't want to quit. So I swallowed my pride, applied for food stamps and low income health insurance for my kids. I then signed a really shitty deal to access the tiny bit of equity I had in my house. I moved my whole family in with my parents and I rented out my house. Between my parents help, $500/month positive cash flow from the rental, a credit card with $6k limit and the government assistance, I was able to live and my children didn't suffer too much.I used the equity in my house to hire a tech firm to build out a prototype of a product idea I had thought of during my first business. (I'm a non-technical founder) I went to our local sheriff's office and asked them if they would be willing to try using the prototype, they said yes. When I ran out of money the prototype was about 40% complete, but the sheriff's office had already made an arrest that they generated from tips delivered through the technology. So, they invited me to present it at their annual conference (I told them I was broke, so they didn't charge me).At the annual conference someone watching my presentation asked me to build a version of the tech for their crime stoppers program. $7,200.I then starting building the tech using the prototype as the base point. At this same time I crossed paths with a friend from college. He was out of work and I asked him to help me. He agreed and he cashed in on a small savings he had and we used that $25k to float us.At the same time all of this was happening I learned of a local program (Ben Franklin Tech Partnership) that just started to help create tech companies in my area. (Rural Pennsylvania). I contacted the program director she interviewed me and invited me in.I was accepted to their program. The first challenge they gave me was build a team, so I found two brilliant developers that were looking to build names for themselves. We worked out a deal and I had a team. With a team in place, I received an investment of $25k through the program.They then gave me challenge number 2, get a real customer. So I went out and showed several of the regional police departments and district attorney's what I was building. One of them saw the vision, and purchased out tech for the entire county (at a heavy discount), but still a low 6 figure deal.(I'm adding this note because it is important. I have a Sass model, the first county deal was 16 customers and I had them prepay for 3 years of subscription at a heavy discount to generate cash up front. When self funding, this is a crucial trick for success. Prepaid subscriptions)From there we received another investment of $75k. (These investments are designed to create jobs, they go toward payroll) We spent a year building version 1.0 and launched that with 16 police agencies in July, 2013.After that, building on one success after another we received another $225k investment and we now have 55 paying customers.There was a lot of struggle here so I don't want you to think it was easy. And I am by no means yet successful, but my technology works and I built it with hard work and sacrifice!! You can do it too as long as you believe in yourself.UPDATEThere have been many ups and downs since I first wrote this answer. Building a company is the hardest thing I have ever done. Harder than being a father, husband and son. The company is on track to hit 200 customers in 5 states by the end of the year. We have reached break-even after 7/8 years and may actually throw off a little profit for the first time in 2020.We have not raised additional money, despite the constant pressure of feeling like that is a bad idea. We have had plenty of people and groups wanting to own a piece of the company, but I just can’t get past the feeling that everyone is just “playing start-up”.I tell early stage people all the time, focus on building a business. The product, the idea, the business plan they want you to write..it all is meaningless if you’re not cashing checks. Find something that creates value that someone else is willing to pay you for, focus on that and everything else will fall into place!

Just don’t expect to reduce it to practice, without someone renaming it on you.

Answer: While many researchers may be very smart, they are not necessarily business-smart.To start your own business, the most important skill to master is sales. Because who else is going to sell your product? You must have the inner conviction and the ability to sell your new product. Everything else can be outsourced. Nobody else will sell your product for the first time.Researchers, on the other hand, are great at generating new ideas and developing these ideas into papers, specifications, equations, and sometimes real products. But they are certainly less equipped with the skills for predicting tWhile many researchers may be very smart, they are not necessarily business-smart.To start your own business, the most important skill to master is sales. Because who else is going to sell your product? You must have the inner conviction and the ability to sell your new product. Everything else can be outsourced. Nobody else will sell your product for the first time.Researchers, on the other hand, are great at generating new ideas and developing these ideas into papers, specifications, equations, and sometimes real products. But they are certainly less equipped with the skills for predicting the market value of a product. In fact, researchers rarely talk to potential “users” of their products, unless these may be other researchers. Besides, most researchers don’t actually make products. They are there to advance science, to discover something new and interesting (to them). They are usually not interested in interacting with possible “customers” and studying their needs.To summarize: while researchers may be smart, their current method of working is counter-productive to developing real-world products for real-world users.

Answer: I think you really do not understand the terms you are throwing around, if you think they are applicable to the problem space of replicating the product of a successful technology company.Machine leaning is about using very large data sets + algorithms to gain insights you would otherwise not be able to gain, without access to a very large data set, and which a human would never be able to gain at all, because humans are very poor at processing very large data sets.For example, I could likely use machine learning against a very large supermarket chain’s customer frequency marketing card data,I think you really do not understand the terms you are throwing around, if you think they are applicable to the problem space of replicating the product of a successful technology company.Machine leaning is about using very large data sets + algorithms to gain insights you would otherwise not be able to gain, without access to a very large data set, and which a human would never be able to gain at all, because humans are very poor at processing very large data sets.For example, I could likely use machine learning against a very large supermarket chain’s customer frequency marketing card data, which contains [nearly] every product they have ever purchased, and then use that data in combination with a product-to-ingredient database.And then I could tell you who has what food allergies, if not themselves, then in their household.That’s the type of insights that machine learning can provide.In terms of optimization, at present, a good human will always beat a good machine model.Compiler writers like to claim that a human can never write better code than a compiler; I know for a fact, however, that IBM’s XL C fails to handle unaligned memory copies in an optimal way, and turns them into byte-by-byte copies instead, even though there’s a better way in PPC assembly to do this, which ends up on average being about 5X faster.So so much for the theory that machines are better at optimization.A machine can do what a human tells it to do, and even if it can iterate over a large space of possible solutions to narrow in on a good one, it’s more or less a brute force approach; it’s not like pruning decision trees in a computer which plays chess at a very deep level.In terms of AI, it’s a research field.If something useful comes out of it, we rename it into its own technology, spin it off into that category, and then AI is back to being a research field.Do you think personal assistant technology is AI? Optical character recognition? Voice recognition? Face boxing in images?It’s not, or we wouldn’t have those names for it; it’s been spun off, and AI went back to being a research field immediately afterwards.None of this is really readily applicable to replicating someone else’s product.

Look at all the high-profile entrepreneurs who started companies. How many of those have PhDs that have been critical to their success? I’d be surprised if you could name two.

question: https://www.quora.com/Is-there-an-upper-limit-to-how-large-and-profitable-the-top-technology-companies-can-become-Amazon-Google-Apple-etc-or-will-they-keep-growing-forever

Answer: Over the course of my career, I’ve worked for big companies (>100K employees) and little companies (15 people) and companies in between. Big companies can be great places to work and are worth your consideration if you have an offer from one.That said, one of the things about big companies is that they are big. And as a member of a big company (unless you are at the top of the heap) you are very small cog in that big machine. It’s hard to be noticed and in such a large talent pool, it can be easy to be pigeon-holed into doing the same ol’ limited job over and over again.Meanwhile, little compaOver the course of my career, I’ve worked for big companies (>100K employees) and little companies (15 people) and companies in between. Big companies can be great places to work and are worth your consideration if you have an offer from one.That said, one of the things about big companies is that they are big. And as a member of a big company (unless you are at the top of the heap) you are very small cog in that big machine. It’s hard to be noticed and in such a large talent pool, it can be easy to be pigeon-holed into doing the same ol’ limited job over and over again.Meanwhile, little companies also do amazing things (where do you think big companies like Google come from?) And in a little company, your contribution becomes a significant fraction of the project. Instead of being one of a cast of thousands, you are a major contributor. And because little companies are resource limited and don’t have a talent pool with experts in everything, you can get some very interesting opportunities to expand your knowledge and skills. And in a small company, you get to know everyone and everyone knows you. The strongest friendships that came out of my career all came out of working in small companies.Bottom line, small companies can be a great opportunity. Don’t knock them if you haven’t tried them.

Answer: Programming languages are finicky beasts.Misplace a comma and 10,000 lines of code don't compile. Misplace a semi-colon in a C++ header file and watch the fun as the error appears in five other files. Miscode some STL code and read the most inscrutable and cryptic error messages ever.Most of us use the first compile of an update as a syntax check. Did our brackets match? Do all functions have the right number and type of arguments?Run make and see what happens -- all except for a handful of super human programmers.The single most productive developer I've ever seen was a freak of nature. He woProgramming languages are finicky beasts.Misplace a comma and 10,000 lines of code don't compile. Misplace a semi-colon in a C++ header file and watch the fun as the error appears in five other files. Miscode some STL code and read the most inscrutable and cryptic error messages ever.Most of us use the first compile of an update as a syntax check. Did our brackets match? Do all functions have the right number and type of arguments?Run make and see what happens -- all except for a handful of super human programmers.The single most productive developer I've ever seen was a freak of nature. He would read the spec for a class and go to work. For ten minutes, he would sit motionless at the keyboard, hand at the home position, not moving a muscle. Then suddenly, his keyboard would come to life with 30 minutes of nonstop clicking as he typed in one file, then another, then another and another and finally another. Effortlessly he switched from file to file from the keyboard. Then another 10 minutes of motionless silence Wham, he went into a fury of typing for another half an hour.His entire workday was like that.How many compiles did he do in a day?One. The last thing he did before he left was to check for an incredibly rare event: a syntax error from his keyboard. Then he checked in his code and went home.How many compile errors did I see him make?Zero, Nada, Zilch.That is amazing.

Answer: Here is something that comes up often at work that I see great programmers do that average programmers don’t.I’ll give a quick example and then break it down for you…I was on a project recently that was a pretty significant undertaking. Think on the scale of a 6–12 months project.We had a PM who was excited to push us to some arbitrary deadline so that his boss could be happy with him hitting the deadline. There was a nice set of timelines and charts and whoozits and whatsits and so on explaining this brilliant plan.The entire team of developers and QA’s was stoked. We were going to do this inHere is something that comes up often at work that I see great programmers do that average programmers don’t.I’ll give a quick example and then break it down for you…I was on a project recently that was a pretty significant undertaking. Think on the scale of a 6–12 months project.We had a PM who was excited to push us to some arbitrary deadline so that his boss could be happy with him hitting the deadline. There was a nice set of timelines and charts and whoozits and whatsits and so on explaining this brilliant plan.The entire team of developers and QA’s was stoked. We were going to do this in like 2 months with plenty of time to hit the 3 month later launch date. Oh, and this was attached to a larger arbitrary goal (ever heard of OKRs? or KRs? Or Quarterly Targets? Or Big Rocks?, it was one of those deals).After the full presentation of the plan was complete, I raised my hand and asked a question.“That’s a great plan, but what happens when it doesn’t work?”The room filled with silence. I got some sour looks, but I continued.“There are a bunch of unknowns. We don’t know how long issues X, Y, and Z will take at all. We are guessing and hoping for the best. Yet, every time we do this we uncover some messy thing that often takes weeks or months to unravel. What makes you think this will be any different?”The PM went on to explain that we really needed to hit our quarterly targets and that reality was basically unacceptable to them or their boss.I said, “Okay, well best case scenario is 6 months, it will probably take 12. Even if you don’t like it, plan accordingly.”Long story short, it took at least 12 months. I left the team before the project finished.The point of the story is not that I was right. It’s that most programmers love optimistic estimates. They want to say that something will be done quickly so that they look good to their boss and teammates.In almost every case something goes wrong that makes things take longer. Unforeseen problems and so on.In my experience, great programmers know that things will go wrong. They plan for it. They can usually tell you in advance what parts of the software are most likely to cause problems and sometimes even can pinpoint why.Unfortunately, honesty can be quite unpopular as great programmers aren’t often listened to unless they are in a position of authority. It is often the opinion of the most optimistic (or foolish) person that wins the day, even if it leads to catastrophe.Great programmers know-BrianP.S. I write about code and career issues

Answer: Large companies tend to be a good place for new grads to begin their careers. Most large companies will have training programs tailored to new grads and the work environment is more structured (formalized processes for everything, enforced peer reviews, etc).Also, there’s a lot less responsibility when you are employee #25,342 - you just aren’t going to have much of an impact on the business either way, so most of the common newbie mistakes you *will* make in the first few years of your career won’t hurt you much :)However, as an experienced software engineer who recently took a job at a big cLarge companies tend to be a good place for new grads to begin their careers. Most large companies will have training programs tailored to new grads and the work environment is more structured (formalized processes for everything, enforced peer reviews, etc).Also, there’s a lot less responsibility when you are employee #25,342 - you just aren’t going to have much of an impact on the business either way, so most of the common newbie mistakes you *will* make in the first few years of your career won’t hurt you much :)However, as an experienced software engineer who recently took a job at a big company after working at small companies for the last several years, the same attributes of big companies that make them safe places for new grads to get their start make them absolutely maddening for people who know what they’re doing:

Answer: Why whouldn’t they?I’m most certainly not a “top programmer” based on the most common american definition.However my schedule is similar since I code a lot and work on many project at a time.Most of my free time is dedicated to programming, reading and writing CS related stuff.At my day job I'm a 3d developer and integrator so thats also programming.I enjoy cooking with my wife, watching netflix and traveling. On January I'll be a father.Once or twice every 2 weeks I'm going to meetups on crypto currencies, that costs about 1 evening a week.I have 2 hours of travel per day to get to and from mWhy whouldn’t they?I’m most certainly not a “top programmer” based on the most common american definition.However my schedule is similar since I code a lot and work on many project at a time.Most of my free time is dedicated to programming, reading and writing CS related stuff.At my day job I'm a 3d developer and integrator so thats also programming.I enjoy cooking with my wife, watching netflix and traveling. On January I'll be a father.Once or twice every 2 weeks I'm going to meetups on crypto currencies, that costs about 1 evening a week.I have 2 hours of travel per day to get to and from my work. I use this time to read technical docs and watch tv shows on my phone.I then spend the evening with my wife. We listen to the baby's heartbeats, cook and watch a tv show she likes.My wife goes to sleep 3 hours earlier than I do. I use that time to work on my personal projects, so thats about 4x3 = 12 hours of additional work a week.Half of my weekends I get to work a full day. The other day is used for boring stuff like groceries and cleaning up.Sometimes we invite friends for dinner on this day too.The other half we get to travel or visit our families.So basically I feel very active and involved with CS, but my family still gets to see me more than my collegues are seing theirs, if they chose to spend more time at day job to earn more.I believe a lot of "top programmers" are doing very nicely with their social duties too.I wouldn't worry about them.
